thread.title: Clemson has nothing on Oklahoma when it comes to choke jobs
thread.title_full: Clemson has nothing on Oklahoma when it comes to choke jobs

title: Clemson has nothing on Oklahoma when it comes to choke jobs
text:
Clemson has nothing on Oklahoma when it comes to choke jobs Resize Text By Matt Bonesteel October 12 at 12:15 PM Follow @MattBonesteel (AP Photo/LM Otero) 
Any conversation about college football’s biggest collection of chokers usually ends up as a discussion about “Clemsoning,” the Tigers’ near-mystical ability to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory . 
But Clemson has nothing on Oklahoma, college football’s biggest choker. 
It happened again on Saturday, when the Sooners lost to a thoroughly mediocre Texas team as a 17.5-point favorite. 
ESPN’s Jake Trotter says math can prove all this : 
According to the Football Power Index, which is a statistical measure of a team’s supposed strength, Oklahoma had a 90 percent chance of beating Texas. 
Going back five years, the Sooners have six defeats in which FPI gave them at least an 80 percent chance to win. 
According to ESPN Stats & Info, no FBS team has more such losses over that span. Not even Clemson — from which “Clemsoning” entered the college football lexicon to describe when a heavily favored team delivers an inexplicably disappointing losing performance. 
The Sooners can add to that ignoble tally twice more this season , as FPI gives them a 98.4 percent chance of beating Kansas on Oct. 31 and a 94.6 percent chance of beating Iowa State on Nov. 7. After spending the first 17 years of his Post career writing and editing, Matt and the printed paper had an amicable divorce in 2014. He's now blogging and editing for the Early Lead and the Post's other Web-based products. sports Success! Check your inbox for details.
